instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> blown
threads.message:
Have a bad feeling with with this MacBook Air. I have replaced both <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R7200</RESISTOR> and no luck. I'm weirdly getting 8.59 on ppbus. I know that this line is sensitive so im going to guess that even that is too high . 

Also I had to run a Jumper on pin 17.... Pin 16 looked toasty as well. Looks like there was a short between them which would mean PPBUS went directly into a 5V CPU line...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> blown
threads.message:
"<RESISTOR>R7200</RESISTOR>"
Not on schematic.
Check both <RESISTOR>R7201</RESISTOR>/02.

Check <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> basic voltages; pins 1, 16, 17.
Do you get correct voltage on the other big coils?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> blown
threads.message:
sorry yes I meant <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR>. Both sides are 8.59V on that. 
on <RESISTOR>R7201</RESISTOR> it's 0v on both sides 
pin 1 is 0V
Pin 16 0v 
pin 17 8.59v of course 

also checked <RESISTOR>R1951</RESISTOR> just in case. 0V both sides. 

checked all big coils on top. everything is 0V except for L7560 and of course L7130 is 8.59V

I forgot to mention but you probably know anyway. Current state of the MacBook is green/orange light, no fan spin

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> blown
threads.message:
I was thinking you get many more voltages, if went in search of CPU core.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> blown
threads.message:
0V on that. dead short on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>. 0 ohm short 

yes I get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>

Guess it's dead :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> blown
threads.message: im so unlucky with these boards recently wtf

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damage on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, <RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR> blown
threads.message: Lift CPU core coils and confirm if the short is on CPU side.
